description: up- +‎ stage. The figurative uses “haughty” and “to draw attention away” derive from actors moving to a higher and thus more visible position on a sloped stage.

adjectives.description: upstage (comparative more upstage, superlative most upstage)

entries.meaning: At the rear of a stage.
examples: The minimalist play used no upstage scenery.

adverbs.description: upstage (comparative more upstage, superlative most upstage)

entries.meaning: Toward or at the rear of a theatrical stage.
examples: The actor turned and walked upstage.

entries.meaning: Away from the audience or camera.
(theater) The part of a stage that is farthest from the audience or camera.
examples: Coordinate terms: center stage, downstage, stage left, stage right

verbs.description: upstage (third-person singular simple present upstages, present participle upstaging, simple past and past participle upstaged)

entries.meaning: (figurative, transitive) To draw attention away from others, especially on-stage.
examples: She only wore that dress to upstage everyone.

entries.meaning: (transitive, theater) To force other actors to face away from the audience by staying upstage.
(medicine, transitive) To restage upward; to restage (a case of a disease, usually a cancer) to a higher stage than that found at last assessment.
